Jack Shafer


                AP Photo

            By 
Nick Gass

10/06/15 07:53 AM EDT
Donald Trump fired back at the media, calling outlets "dishonest" and "disgusting" on Tuesday for twisting his words about when he would potentially drop out of the race for the Republican nomination. Trump's message: "I'm going all the way."
"Not even a thought. Look, it's a phony deal that was perpetrated on the public," Trump told CNN's Chris Cuomo in a telephone interview on "New Day."
Story Continued Below
During interviews aired this Sunday on ABC and NBC, Trump laid out a hypothetical scenario in which he would consider abandoning his bid for the White House. 
"Number one, I'm not a masochist. And if I was dropping in the polls where I saw that I wasn't gonna win, why would I continue? And it's funny. Maybe it's, like, not like me because it's the power of positive thinking -- I'm a very positive person, I'm a positive thinker -- but the truth is, I'm a realist. I'm doing great in the polls right now, I think you will say. I'm not saying anything. I'm leading everything, right?" Trump asked NBC's Chuck Todd.
The real-estate mogul unloaded on media coverage of the remark.
"Let me make it a little bit different: I’m not getting out. I’m gonna win, OK? I gave a very honest answer, but the press takes an answer like that and they make it like, oh, there's a big story, they make headlines out of it. It’s ridiculous," Trump declared. "The question was: Would you get out? The answer is: I’m going all the way and we’re going to win. It’s a simpler answer and people can’t play around with that. I mean, I watch these politicians — you know they’re getting out in the next two weeks and they say, 'Oh, I’m never getting out.' They’re not telling the truth."
During the segment, which lasted more than 20 minutes, he also defended his wait-and-see approach on Syria regarding Russia's involvement in the region on Tuesday, insisting that it would not be "trusting Russia."
"Well now they're supposedly hitting ISIS, which is a positive thing and you know my attitude is we're backing rebels, we have no idea who they are," Trump said on CNN's "New Day," reacting to reports that Moscow was hitting Islamic State targets in the modern city of Palmyra. "Frankly, every time we just get bogged down in the Middle East and Russia will get bogged down in the Middle East," he added.
On the region as a whole, Trump warned that the U.S. does not know exactly who the rebels are that it is supporting in Syria.
Syrian President Bashar Assad "is a bad guy, but you can have worse," he said, "and maybe these people are worse, we have no idea. I spoke to a general the other day, who's very well-versed in the area, he said, 'We have no idea who these people are we're backing.'"
If Assad's regime were still in place, Trump said, "you wouldn't have the migration of millions of people and all of the problems that that's causing. And death, death all over the place."
“I’m just saying, sit back, just take it easy, just relax, save your billions of dollars, let’s build some bridges, let’s fix the roadways in our country, let’s rebuild America, make America great again, let’s rebuild our military," he told Cuomo of his thinking.
On Afghanistan, Trump said that he would "begrudgingly" keep boots on the ground, as President Barack Obama has said, because otherwise the country would "collapse after two seconds" if the U.S. left now.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: Trump: 'I'm going all the way'
